Title.evidence: Bypass Angioplasty Revascularization Investigation 2 Diabetes (BARI 2D): A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: This randomised controlled trial used a 2 Ã— 2 factorial design.

Participants.evidence: Participants were diabetic patients with myocardial ischemia and multivessel coronary artery disease.

Intervention.evidence: 173 were randomised to early CABG and 174 to medical management.

Objective.evidence: The study aimed to compare early revascularization with medical management and insulin sensitization with insulin provision.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the rate of subsequent myocardial infarction, measured over a follow-up period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not applicable due to the nature of the interventions.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 347 patients were randomised to early coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) or medical management.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on an intention-to-treat basis.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Early CABG resulted in a significant reduction in myocardial infarction rates compared to medical management (hazard ratio = 0.70, 95% CI 0.50 to 0.98; p = 0.04).

Harms.evidence: Perioperative morbidity and mortality were low, with no significant differences in adverse events between groups.
